column13: GUAC-1389: Add screen sharing support to telnet.
GUAC-246: Implement screen recording

GUAC-236: Do not use features specific to libjpeg-turbo. Ensure compatibility with libjpeg.
column20:
The JCS_EXT_BGRX colorspace is convenient as it's exactly equivalent to Cairo's formats, but it's specific to libjpeg-turbo. Using that colorspace means guacenc fails to build against libjpeg, which is bad.
This change uses libjpeg's standard JCS_RGB and translates to Cairo's formats, rather than relying on features specific to libjpeg-turbo.
column21:
The JCS_EXT_BGRX colorspace is convenient as it's exactly equivalent to Cairo's formats, but it's specific to libjpeg-turbo. Using that colorspace means guacenc fails to build against libjpeg, which is bad.
This change uses libjpeg's standard JCS_RGB and translates to Cairo's formats, rather than relying on features specific to libjpeg-turbo.

column13: GUAC-236: Provide support for much older versions of libavcodec.
GUAC-1164: Add parameter for automatically reconnecting when display changes
column20: This change adds a new "reconnect-method" parameter for RDP which accepts two values: "reconnect", which disconnects and reconnects the RDP session when the screen size changes, and "display-update", which uses the "Display Update" channel available with RDP 8.1+. If the parameter is left blank, screen size changes are simply ignored.
column21: This change adds a new "reconnect-method" parameter for RDP which accepts two values: "reconnect", which disconnects and reconnects the RDP session when the screen size changes, and "display-update", which uses the "Display Update" channel available with RDP 8.1+. If the parameter is left blank, screen size changes are simply ignored.

Hi @tylermauthe,
Just saw this PR open (and close). In case of confusion, though I expect this may be why you closed the PR in the first place, the Guacamole project has moved to the Apache Incubator, as have the repositories. The new guacamole-server repository is here:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-guacamole-server
I went ahead and moved the original GUAC-1509 issue in the Glyptodon JIRA to GUACAMOLE-39 in the Apache JIRA. If you wish to open a new pull request, please do so against the new repository (and the new issue). Thanks!

column13: Include FFMPEG/Guacenc
column20:
The current docker image guacd does not include the guacenc utility.  Installing ffmpeg allows this to build and be included.
I imagine there are licensing issues that might prevent this pull from being accepted, but wanted to pass along how we're using it just in case it is useful.  Is there a better way to ensure guacenc is included in the build, and or is there a way we can get this into the official image?
column21:

I imagine there are licensing issues that might prevent this pull from being accepted, but wanted to pass along how we're using it just in case it is useful.  Is there a better way to ensure guacenc is included in the build, and or is there a way we can get this into the official image?

column13: Include FFMPEG/Guacenc
column20:
The current docker image guacd does not include the guacenc utility.  Installing ffmpeg allows this to build and be included.
I imagine there are licensing issues that might prevent this pull from being accepted, but wanted to pass along how we're using it just in case it is useful.  Is there a better way to ensure guacenc is included in the build, and or is there a way we can get this into the official image?
column21:
The Guacamole project has moved to the Apache Incubator, as have the repositories, and the Docker images have been merged into the repositories for guacamole-client and guacamole-server. In this case, the relevant repository would be:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-guacamole-server
That said:
guacenc is intentionally excluded. The intent of the guacd Docker image is to provide guacd and only guacd. The guacenc utility, if required, is expected would need to be installed and run outside the container. Besides separation of concerns, running guacenc on a separate server helps prevent using up resources with video encoding, part of the reason that functionality was kept as a standalone utility.

column13: GLYP-31: Merge 256-color terminal changes from GUACAMOLE-278 and GUACAMOLE-280.
column20:
This should be identical to the changes introduced via GUACAMOLE-278 and GUACAMOLE-80:
$ git log --pretty=oneline --merges incubator/master | grep 'GUACAMOLE-280\>\|GUACAMOLE-278\>'
9ee224f2ca3a57bb8212574f78171cfc76196adf GUACAMOLE-280: Merge low intensity SGR option.
04205a9b979077580f2e2a10746797a6bab4c4e7 GUACAMOLE-278: Merge counter fix for SGR parser.
0e5498fc83a05aebbc9558a4503af8c92abfdac6 GUACAMOLE-278: Merge SGR bright color support for terminal.
d88b5d1011e7d9dd0ce201ad1fabda7394a1287c GUACAMOLE-278: Merge 256-color support for terminal.
$ 

The above merges should correspond to the following upstream pull requests:

apache/guacamole-server#86
apache/guacamole-server#88
apache/guacamole-server#90
apache/guacamole-server#92
column21:
OK, it seems this really is the best way to go. There are three options overall:

Merge upstream normally, reverting any undesired commits individually via additional commits from git revert.
Rebase the upstream commits onto the divergent downstream branch.
Cherry-pick the upstream merge commit, resulting in a single non-merge commit containing the squashed upstream changes (git cherry-pick -x -m1 UPSTREAM_MERGE_COMMIT).

Option 1 would become rapidly unmaintainable as the number of undesired commits grows, and would make things awkward when previously-reverted commits are accepted later. The git history would be crazy.
Option 2 would work decently, but would be difficult in practice for larger changes or for sufficiently-divergent bases. Rather than dealing with merge conflicts on the overall merge result, conflicts would need to be dealt with every step of the way, even when the associated commits are ultimately immaterial to the final result or irrelevant to the diverged base.
That leaves option 3, which works absolutely fine with the exception of the loss of underlying history, but that may just be a fact we need to accept. When changes are backported in this manner, they really are separate and new changes, and thus warrant fresh commits.

column13: GLEN-115: Backport build changes supporting out-of-tree builds
column20:
Upstream has recently modified the guacamole-server build such that it correctly builds out-of-tree. This is nice, but results in merge conflicts for all backports after that point in history.
For the sake of any future backports, including those slated for 1.6, this change should be backported as well.

column13: GLEN-109: Additionally backport RDP keymaps for Turkish-Q and Spanish keyboards.
GLEN-123: Add support for changing SSH/telnet window title
column20:
These changes, combining upstream GUACAMOLE-265 and GUACAMOLE-502, are the server-side changes required by glyptodon/guacamole-client#365.
GUACAMOLE-265 adds the base support for sending the "name" instruction in response to the terminal code used to change window title, while GUACAMOLE-502 fixes the behavioral regression in the handling of connection name/title for VNC and RDP which resulted from those changes. Together, these changes add the necessary support in a stable manner.
column21:
These changes, combining upstream GUACAMOLE-265 and GUACAMOLE-502, are the server-side changes required by glyptodon/guacamole-client#365.
GUACAMOLE-265 adds the base support for sending the "name" instruction in response to the terminal code used to change window title, while GUACAMOLE-502 fixes the behavioral regression in the handling of connection name/title for VNC and RDP which resulted from those changes. Together, these changes add the necessary support in a stable manner.

column13: GLEN-121: Address potential segfault during SSH disconnect.
column20:
From upstream GUACAMOLE-384:

Looks like the terminal is being freed during normal connection cleanup, but prior to the SSH client thread finishing. Depending on timing, attempts to write to the terminal by the SSH client thread segfault since the terminal was already freed.
This needs to be fixed, but will not affect the stability of connections in practice, as the segfault is occurring during normal disconnect.
...
Yes, that's what I meant by the comment above.
The thread in this case is the SSH client thread, created to handle the underlying SSH connection after the first user joins:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-guacamole-server/blob/d35cc7a83e8dfdaa44cbd3b02c70e9407197155a/src/protocols/ssh/user.c#L56-L70
If you look at the free handler for the guac_client created for the SSH connection, you can see that the terminal is freed prior to waiting for the thread to finish:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-guacamole-server/blob/d35cc7a83e8dfdaa44cbd3b02c70e9407197155a/src/protocols/ssh/client.c#L73-L74
This creates a race condition which could result in data being written by the client thread to the freed terminal, causing a segfault. The fix may be as simple as switching the order of those lines, but such a change will need to be carefully verified. The SSH client thread depends on certain conditions for the thread to terminate. If switching those lines results in a chance of those conditions not occurring, then we'll be replacing a low-impact segfault with high-impact deadlock.
The SSH client and input threads should probably take the client running state into account (the value manipulated by guac_client_stop()), to ensure they will terminate regardless of the current state of the terminal or underlying SSH connection.
column21:
From upstream GUACAMOLE-384:

Looks like the terminal is being freed during normal connection cleanup, but prior to the SSH client thread finishing. Depending on timing, attempts to write to the terminal by the SSH client thread segfault since the terminal was already freed.
This needs to be fixed, but will not affect the stability of connections in practice, as the segfault is occurring during normal disconnect.
...
Yes, that's what I meant by the comment above.
The thread in this case is the SSH client thread, created to handle the underlying SSH connection after the first user joins:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-guacamole-server/blob/d35cc7a83e8dfdaa44cbd3b02c70e9407197155a/src/protocols/ssh/user.c#L56-L70
If you look at the free handler for the guac_client created for the SSH connection, you can see that the terminal is freed prior to waiting for the thread to finish:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-guacamole-server/blob/d35cc7a83e8dfdaa44cbd3b02c70e9407197155a/src/protocols/ssh/client.c#L73-L74
This creates a race condition which could result in data being written by the client thread to the freed terminal, causing a segfault. The fix may be as simple as switching the order of those lines, but such a change will need to be carefully verified. The SSH client thread depends on certain conditions for the thread to terminate. If switching those lines results in a chance of those conditions not occurring, then we'll be replacing a low-impact segfault with high-impact deadlock.
The SSH client and input threads should probably take the client running state into account (the value manipulated by guac_client_stop()), to ensure they will terminate regardless of the current state of the terminal or underlying SSH connection.

GLEN-235: Backport fixes for known regressions related to the FreeRDP 2.0.0 migration.
column20:
This change backports the fixes for all known regressions from the Apache Guacamole 1.1.0 migration to FreeRDP 2.0.0 which have been accepted and merged upstream for the 1.2.0 release.
Except for these specific issues, there have been no other regressions encountered which were not due to FreeRDP 2.0.0-rc0 as packaged by Ubuntu 18.04.

column13: GLEN-216: Backport migration to FreeRDP 2.0.0.
column20:
This backporting effort is significantly more complex than others due to the size of the changes involved and the way those changes have been built on the various other changes made since 0.9.12-incubating.
To manage to backport things successfully, this set of changes takes the following approach:

Backport features that would both be beneficial and would reduce the amount of manual changes required to make the FreeRDP 2.0.0 changes compatible:

Support for configuring the SFTP root directory (#190)
Support for configuring SSH host key checking (#191)


Backport known dependencies through the usual "cherry-pick" method:

Migration to the new unit test tooling (#193)
Additional string utility functions within libguac (#194).


Copy over the RDP support from the glyptodon/2.x branch verbatim.
Make as minimal changes as possible to bring that support back into compatibility with glyptodon/1.x:

Use the common session recording API that was part of 0.9.12 guacamole-server (no recording of input events)
Remove trace-level logging (not part of 0.9.12 libguac)
Remove use of Guacamole protocol error codes that were not part of the 0.9.12 version of the protocol
Correct calls to the common SSH utility functions.
Remove reliance on the user timezone handshake (not part of the Guacamole protocol until way after 0.9.12)
Remove any settings not already part of glyptodon/1.x, #190, or #191.



With these changes made, glyptodon/1.x builds against FreeRDP 2.0.0 just as glyptodon/2.x but remains completely compatible.

column13: GLEN-216: Backport new string utility functions from newer libguac.
column20:
Another dependency of the FreeRDP 2.0.0 support, this change backports the new string utility functions provided by newer versions of libguac.
As the new functions are not present in the 0.9.12 version of libguac, and this might result in downstream usage of the library being incompatible with the intended base version, this change also guards those functions behind a GLEN_SOURCE macro. The GLEN_SOURCE macro must be explicitly defined if these functions are to be available.

The GLEN_SOURCE macro must be explicitly defined if these functions are to be available.

GLEN-259: Bring 2.x source tree for guacamole-server up-to-date with current upstream staging/1.3.0.
column20:
These changes merge absolutely everything from the current upstream staging/1.3.0 branch, bringing the guacamole-server portion of the GLEN 2.x source tree up-to-date with the latest changes pending upstream release.
Naturally, this changeset is huge. I've intentionally kept things isolated to a single merge commit which establishes what exactly has been merged (upstream commit 7fcddef). Comparing the source tree against that commit, the only differences should be version number suffixes.

column13: GLEN-259: Backport fix for VNC build on EL6.
column20:
The version of libvncclient packaged by CentOS / RHEL 6 lacks the GetCredential callback. The guacamole-server source leverages this callback for the VNC support since GUACAMOLE-514 (part of Apache Guacamole 1.2.0), resulting in a build failure. With the upcoming GLEN 2.2 release intended to be based off upcoming Apache Guacamole 1.3.0, our builds for the EL6 platform are also currently failing.
This change backports the build fix introduced by GUACAMOLE-1227, making the relevant code conditional and correcting the build.

With the upcoming GLEN 2.2 release intended to be based off upcoming Apache Guacamole 1.3.0, our builds for the EL6 platform are also currently failing.
This change backports the build fix introduced by GUACAMOLE-1227, making the relevant code conditional and correcting the build.

column13: GLEN-261: Backport support for libuuid to GLEN 2.x.
column20: RHEL 6 does not include a uuid-devel package (the OSSP UUID library). It does provide a libuuid-devel package (the library from util-linux). For our builds to leverage RHEL rather than CentOS (see comment on GLEN-261), the recent upstream support for libuuid needs to be backported.

GLEN-182: Correct GCC 7 sprintf() warning resulting in GLEN 1.x build failure on RHEL 8.
column20: A warning regarding sprintf() specific to GCC 7 was corrected upstream via GUACAMOLE-500 for 1.0.0 and later. As the base version of Guacamole packaged by Glyptodon Enterprise 1.x is earlier than this (0.9.12-incubating), the build fails with a warning on RHEL 8.

GLEN-242: Automatically throttle RDP audio input transmission rate.
column20:
The RDP specification for the AUDIO_INPUT channel requires that all audio be sent in packets of a specific size. Guacamole does correctly limit itself to sending packets of this size to the RDP server, but will send quite a few of these packets all at once if it has received more audio data than the RDP packet size. This is OK in principle (the Guacamole client should be able to send audio in packets of whatever size it chooses), but may overwhelm the software running within the RDP server if the amount of data received exceeds the available buffer space, resulting in dropped samples.
As there is no way to know the size of the remote audio buffer, we need to instead ensure that audio is streamed as close to real time as possible, with each audio packet of N bytes not being sent until roughly the amount of time represented by those N bytes has elapsed since the last packet. This throttling ensures that software expecting to process audio in real time should never run out of buffer space.
column21:
The RDP specification for the AUDIO_INPUT channel requires that all audio be sent in packets of a specific size. Guacamole does correctly limit itself to sending packets of this size to the RDP server, but will send quite a few of these packets all at once if it has received more audio data than the RDP packet size. This is OK in principle (the Guacamole client should be able to send audio in packets of whatever size it chooses), but may overwhelm the software running within the RDP server if the amount of data received exceeds the available buffer space, resulting in dropped samples.
As there is no way to know the size of the remote audio buffer, we need to instead ensure that audio is streamed as close to real time as possible, with each audio packet of N bytes not being sent until roughly the amount of time represented by those N bytes has elapsed since the last packet. This throttling ensures that software expecting to process audio in real time should never run out of buffer space.

column13: GLEN-307: Add proper definition of "Meta" key for RDP.
GLEN-171: Correct management of resources allocated during (re)connect.
column20:
Compared to all other supported protocols, the "Reconnect" resize method of Guacamole's RDP support uniquely requires that the underlying RDP connection be torn down and reinstated, and thus requires that associated resources are properly freed and reallocated when associated only with that session.
Current handling of those resources is incorrect:

Pointers to channel resources from the previous RDP connection remain, resulting in assertion failures and disconnects if the features provided by those channels happen to be used before the new instances of those channels are connected.
Session recordings are allocated within each RDP connection, rather than the single logical Guacamole connection managing those RDP connections. This results in new recordings being created for each reconnect, rather than a single continuous recording representing the overall connection.

These changes correct the above.

column13: Added support for functions keys f1-f12 with SHIFT key.
column20:
Added support for the shift+function key functionality at terminal.c file in both SSH and telnet.
Tested using the “showkey -a” by deploying it on the ssh server and checking the sent key commands.
